To the very polite attention of Captain Crabtree, Of
The fast sailing regular packet ship Richmond which
arrived in Hampton Roads on Saturday evening
last, in 81 days from Liverpool, are indebted fol
papers Of that city from the lib to 10Th January
from which we make some interesting extracts.


Beacon.

King and commander of the army, died on the 5h
January, after long illness Of dropsy-the papers

event


Cotton had remained very langud during the

affairs ,rith Spain.-On the subject Of the Bit
ish negoliations with Spain, Blinge's Liverpool Ad
vertiser Of 10th Jan. observes -" Nothing dehn-
tive is yet known as 10 the state OF the negotiations
with Spain. The rumours in general are OF war
like nature, and there is really reason to fear that
Ferdinand will risk war rather than accede to the
just claims Of this country and OF Portugal. The
Qnotidisane, French ultra paper, and the organ Of
the Apostocals states positively that Ferdinand has
rejected the demands Of the British Government
with more hrmness than civty; and the London
Courier, paper likely TO be we'll acquanted with
the matter, speaks of the state OF the negotiations
most unsatisfactory. Iis stated that the Church.
the only body possessed Of wealth in Spain, has Of
frred 20 support Ferdinand with all its treasure and
its influence, and an army estimated at from 10
10000 men, is assembling the frontiers Of Portu
gal. This looks more like var Than peace"


"W We stated some weeks since, that the King Of
France had caused il to be communicated to our
Government that he had formally apprised Ferdi
nand Of his determination TO recol the Swiss troops
II he persisted 10 course OF conduct towards Por
tugal, such as England and France must equally dis
approve of The policy Of Ferdinand, subsequent
ly 10 receiring that intimaon, has certainly mol
been coniormable to the just expectations Of the
two Powers above named and it followed as mat
Ter Ct course, that what was threatened would be
ecntsd. II need not surprise therefore, TO learn
that positive orders have been sent to Madrid, for
the return Of The Swiss troops, Immediately or
tina, Ferdinand prepared for such orders, has cal
cuasd, We will not say with wha, prudence, upon the
consequences II is evident he considers himself
strong enough 10 set both England and France al de-
hance; while every stsp he takes in the desperate
path Of resistance, will only render future adjust.
meni more difficult more humilis,ing."

and traders are imposingly called. have been held
at New York, Philadelphia, and Baltimore. to re-
solre against the new proposed duty on wool and
wooden goods, and many things stated by them arc
on the high pressure" principle, indeed; but We

stances. Ii cannot escape the recollection Of any

the prophecies of the merchants and Of the " cham
bers Of commerce" as little regarded as II they
had been uttered at period beyond the flood; and
in truth, the merchants, themselves, have neW com
modi,ies for export, in manufactured goods, OF

exported from the United States, and the tonnags
Of the vessels employed in the foreign trade has

and the rates OF duties that were called almost pro
hibitory," deceptive" "perncious," "ruinnus,' :

not take up the room that is due TO other subjects

like the present. But when we call 10 mind what
We certainly believe is fact, susceptible OF the
clearesi demonstration, that the manufacturers OF
Lad. .l1I;a pJ all lne
several times greater than foreign commerce sup
plies, little astonished at the doings oithe

pecaily when it is perfectly under stood that three

ported arc introduced into our country ard forced

haps. bring up some of the doings OF " chambers

aged. Il will be recoec,ed, tina, twenty five ind

was dlsavowsd; the late meeting was, perhaps, less

inquiry we cannot gather any information about i
and IN Philadelphia, too, tthe chamber Of com
merceo which has also forwarded resolutions .oI
the Senate Of the United States, 10 prevent the

ell told, Of thirty five persona several OF whom
we're opposed to the proceedings or mere lockers
on And these are given out representing the
interests and feelings Of the whole commercial
community The statements published, as 10 the
probable operation OF the bill should it be passed
INTO law, are extremely coored-we will no, say,
grossly exaggerated; but our opinion is, that i the
protection contemplated was really extended to The
growth OF wool and manufacture Of wooden goods,
VIC should eaport the latter in large amounts in ess
than ak years, IN like manner as We now export
cotton goods-and thus do away the possibility o,
saying that such protection was tax upon con
sumption. And We think that our opinion is worth
as much as merchants, seeing that We prophecied
truly as to The fleets oil The present tariff, and the
merchants did net.

The New York House of Assembly, decided on
the 9th instant, that James Kenyon, Quaker pres-
cher, who had been elected to that House, was ex-
cluded therefrom, by the annexed provision OF the
State Constitution


And whereas the preachers Of the gospel are BY
their profession dedicated 10 the service OF God, and
the care Of souls and ought no, TO be diverted from
the great duties of their functions therefore no
minister Of the gospel, prizes, OF any denomination
whatever, shall a. any time hereafter, under any
peence description whstever, be eligible TO, or
capable Of holding any civil or military ofhce or
place within this State

Of the Gospel

BY gentlemen just arrived from Col. Austin's
settlement, Texas, We are informed tina, Governor
Saucedo has arrived there from ST. Antonio, with
one hundred and 6tty Mexican troops, on his way
10 Nacogdoches, TO suppress the nsurrsction which
exists there. On the arrival OF the Governor st
Colonel Ausns settlement he called on the Col
cnel to know what part he intended TO act, when
Col. Austin Informed him tha, he should act en- the
part of the Mexican Government, and at the re-.
quest OF Governor Saucedo, Immediately called q
meeting OF the Alcaldss in the settlement, who
unanimously resolved to support the Mexican Co
ysrnment in opposition to the i" Freedoniansn


Immediately after the conference with Colonel
Austin, the Empresato Of the District, and the
Alcaidas OF the same District Gov. Saucedo sent
Commissioners 10 Nacogdoches, to treat with the
insurgents, (or Freedonians as they term tn. m
selses,) for reconciliation. On the arrival of The
Commissioners at Nacogdochcs, the insurgents re
FUSED 10 hold Treaty upon any consideration, un.
less tae Mexican Government would acknowl ledee e
them Free and Independent 2 when the Com
mssoners though, it time to be of.


We have not been able 10 ascertain what mea
sures the Governor would adopt, as our iniormants
ett the District previou. to the return Of the Com
missoners


These new Republicans, from all accounts, ap.
pear TO be sangnlne in their novel undertaking, and
from all appearances, bid fair 10 become rivals, In
lame at least, 70 Guliivars Lillipuiians. Notwith
ing the absurdty Of this attempt at freedom in The
opinion Of many, it will cost the Mexicans eres,
trouble, and a very heavy expense TO suppress the
insurrectlon and, il the numerous nations Of Indi
ans who inha5it the Province, are as determined on
keeping the country independent as represented, il
will De long and savage war. but, in our opinion
they will be eventually extermina,ed, or driven ts
the Rocky Mountains, where they will be as Tree
a. air.


1he number o Indians in the Province i. ye.,
large It is said BY some who have been among
the Commanchos, that they have between FIVE sne
six thousand Warriors; others estimate their mum
oels 10 be between ten and fifteen thousand. Thes,
Indians have been at war with the Spaniards, evel
since they have bsen in the country, but the
warfare has been, OF lale, carried on BY small par
lies, whose principal object is plunder There ar.
fifteen or twenty o:her tribes, but their numbers
are small, Cour;.r

Extract q Letter from an American Citizen, dated


Flo JAsEIRo, Nov. s, 1896.


Slave vessels arrive every day or TWO from the
coast OF Africa. with full cargoes OF from Two hun.
dfed and fifty TO three and lout hundred Neeroe.
= day or Two since saw drove of them on shore
sar sale, with little white boy driving them along
ne street, as they drive sheep in our country The
Negroes arc driven 70 market and tried, 10 see
lhs! they are sound in limb and body. They are
soid Tor from two TO three hundred dollars each.


:. i was certainly aheart-rending sight, and when
otheld the poor Negroes on shore performing ali
Ands ot labor such as our horses and oxen are
accustomed . do at home, rejoced that the hu
name laws 0! the United States furnish our own
Slaves with 81 y comparatively h'ppy lot"

and traders are imposingly called. have been held
at New York, Philadelphia, and Baltimore. to re-
solre against the new proposed duty on wool and
wooden goods, and many things stated by them arc
on the high pressure" principle, indeed; but We
have not time loom to offer our objections to
them now, as we would do, under different crcum.
stances. Ii cannot escape the recollection Of any
one that this same class OF persons, or bodies Of
individuals as decidedly resolved against the pre-.
sen, tariff, solemnly predicting the ruin Of the
revenue, the excess Of smuggling, the destruction
Of commerce, and ta.ring of the many for the
benefit of the felo with other terrible evils and a.
bominable things that would most certainly happen,
if the scheme then projected for the protection OF
American manufactures and the building up OF a
" home market for American Agriculturaliss,
was carried into effect; but the great leading ea-
tures Of the projected tariff we're established, and
the prophecies of the merchants and Of the " cham
bers Of commerce" as little regarded as II they
had been uttered at period beyond the flood; and
in truth, the merchants, themselves, have neW com
modi,ies for export, in manufactured goods, OF
greater value than the whole amount OF the Hour
exported from the United States, and the tonnags
Of the vessels employed in the foreign trade has
very considerably increased, since the time when !,
was resolved that commerce would be destroyed !;
and the rates OF duties that were called almost pro
hibitory," deceptive" "perncious," "ruinnus,' :





Gle really protected to the consumer, without at all
diminishing the general business Of commercial
men Our fingers are itching TO write down some
Of the doleful sayings OF 1898 and contrast them
with the sober results that followed; but we dare
not take up the room that is due TO other subjects
more properly belonging TO this work and at time
like the present. But when we call 10 mind what
We certainly believe is fact, susceptible OF the
clearesi demonstration, that the manufacturers OF
Lad. .l1I;a pJ all lne
several times greater than foreign commerce sup
plies, little astonished at the doings oithe
Z" chambers Of commerce in these cities. and es.
pecaily when it is perfectly under stood that three
tourlhs or four 6fhs oil all the wooden goods i'm
ported arc introduced into our country ard forced
into consumption ON foreign account We shall
speak at large. these things hereafter, and. per
haps. bring up some of the doings OF " chambers
OF commerce. which are oi,entimes queerfy man
aged. Il will be recoec,ed, tina, twenty five ind
vduals in Baltimore. calling themselves " the cham
Der Of commerce." in Feb 822, OF whom 8 voted
one way and ~ the other, undertook to resore
aroy long established principles in regard 10 The
West India trade, and were laughed al Tor Their
presumption, and the act OF the mn)1rRy Of one
was dlsavowsd; the late meeting was, perhaps, less
respectable Tor its number--but alter considerable
inquiry we cannot gather any information about i
and IN Philadelphia, too, tthe chamber Of com
merceo which has also forwarded resolutions .oI
the Senate Of the United States, 10 prevent the
passage OF the bill before that body consisted,
ell told, Of thirty five persona several OF whom
we're opposed to the proceedings or mere lockers
on And these are given out representing the
interests and feelings Of the whole commercial
community The statements published, as 10 the
probable operation OF the bill should it be passed
INTO law, are extremely coored-we will no, say,
grossly exaggerated; but our opinion is, that i the
protection contemplated was really extended to The
growth OF wool and manufacture Of wooden goods,
VIC should eaport the latter in large amounts in ess
than ak years, IN like manner as We now export
cotton goods-and thus do away the possibility o,
saying that such protection was tax upon con
sumption. And We think that our opinion is worth
as much as merchants, seeing that We prophecied
truly as to The fleets oil The present tariff, and the
merchants did net.

full articles.headline: LATEST FROM TEXAS.
full articles.article:
BY gentlemen just arrived from Col. Austin's
settlement, Texas, We are informed tina, Governor
Saucedo has arrived there from ST. Antonio, with
one hundred and 6tty Mexican troops, on his way
10 Nacogdoches, TO suppress the nsurrsction which
exists there. On the arrival OF the Governor st
Colonel Ausns settlement he called on the Col
cnel to know what part he intended TO act, when
Col. Austin Informed him tha, he should act en- the
part of the Mexican Government, and at the re-.
quest OF Governor Saucedo, Immediately called q
meeting OF the Alcaldss in the settlement, who
unanimously resolved to support the Mexican Co
ysrnment in opposition to the i" Freedoniansn


Immediately after the conference with Colonel
Austin, the Empresato Of the District, and the
Alcaidas OF the same District Gov. Saucedo sent
Commissioners 10 Nacogdoches, to treat with the
insurgents, (or Freedonians as they term tn. m
selses,) for reconciliation. On the arrival of The
Commissioners at Nacogdochcs, the insurgents re
FUSED 10 hold Treaty upon any consideration, un.
less tae Mexican Government would acknowl ledee e
them Free and Independent 2 when the Com
mssoners though, it time to be of.


We have not been able 10 ascertain what mea
sures the Governor would adopt, as our iniormants
ett the District previou. to the return Of the Com
missoners


These new Republicans, from all accounts, ap.
pear TO be sangnlne in their novel undertaking, and
from all appearances, bid fair 10 become rivals, In
lame at least, 70 Guliivars Lillipuiians. Notwith
ing the absurdty Of this attempt at freedom in The
opinion Of many, it will cost the Mexicans eres,
trouble, and a very heavy expense TO suppress the
insurrectlon and, il the numerous nations Of Indi
ans who inha5it the Province, are as determined on
keeping the country independent as represented, il
will De long and savage war. but, in our opinion
they will be eventually extermina,ed, or driven ts
the Rocky Mountains, where they will be as Tree
a. air.


1he number o Indians in the Province i. ye.,
large It is said BY some who have been among
the Commanchos, that they have between FIVE sne
six thousand Warriors; others estimate their mum
oels 10 be between ten and fifteen thousand. Thes,
Indians have been at war with the Spaniards, evel
since they have bsen in the country, but the
warfare has been, OF lale, carried on BY small par
lies, whose principal object is plunder There ar.
fifteen or twenty o:her tribes, but their numbers
are small, Cour;.r

Slave vessels arrive every day or TWO from the
coast OF Africa. with full cargoes OF from Two hun.
dfed and fifty TO three and lout hundred Neeroe.
= day or Two since saw drove of them on shore
sar sale, with little white boy driving them along
ne street, as they drive sheep in our country The
Negroes arc driven 70 market and tried, 10 see
lhs! they are sound in limb and body. They are
soid Tor from two TO three hundred dollars each.


:. i was certainly aheart-rending sight, and when
otheld the poor Negroes on shore performing ali
Ands ot labor such as our horses and oxen are
accustomed . do at home, rejoced that the hu
name laws 0! the United States furnish our own
Slaves with 81 y comparatively h'ppy lot"
